Award.AwardTitle: SHINE: Plasma Instabilities in Post-Eruption Solar Corona, Formation of Plasmoids and Supra-Arcade Downflows
Award.AbstractNarration:
This 3-year SHINE project is aimed at studying plasma instabilities in the solar corona during coronal mass ejections by means to 3-D numerical simulations in realistic coronal configurations. Although the emphasis of this project is on solar physics, the research outcome has broader implications for the Earth's magnetotail, dayside magnetopause, fusion plasmas, and astrophysics. The research will be carried out at the newly established Princeton Center for Heliospheric Physics, which promotes interdisciplinary and international collaborations between basic plasma physicists and solar observers. These collaborations are pursued in synergy with the Max-Planck/Princeton Center for Plasma Physics, which is funded jointly by the NSF, DoE, Max Planck Institute, and Princeton University. This research project will involve a graduate student and a female postdoctoral fellow, and it will contribute to the training of scientists with backgrounds in both solar observations and numerical modeling. Some aspects of the research program are tightly coupled to the academic program in plasma physics at Princeton University, and there will be a new course in space and astrophysical plasma physics to be taught at the Department of Astrophysical Sciences by the Co-PI. The research and EPO agenda of this project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.


The main goal of this SHINE project is to investigate the cause of current sheet broadening and the physical origin of supra-arcade downflows (SADs) during a coronal mass ejection (CME). The three major tasks of this project are to investigate: (1) the role of plasmoid instabilities in producing turbulent reconnection in line-tied coronal current sheets, and the role such turbulence plays in the observed broadening of current sheets; (2) the role of secondary Rayleigh-Taylor type instabilities in reconnection exhaust regions in producing the observed characteristics of SADs; and, (3) the formation of plasmoids and SADs during a CME. One important aspect of this project is to foster cross-comparison, verification, and validation between simulations and solar observations. One of the major goals is to establish the capability of capturing coronal eruption, plasmoid formation, and SADs within a single simulation. The results of this project are expected to further advance our understanding in how the magnetic energy is stored and released in large-scale systems such as the solar corona.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this award period, we have achieved the following accomplishments. 

(1) We demonstrated that the plasmoid instability could facilitate self-generated turbulent reconnection without the need of external forcing. We have quantified the characteristics of the resulting turbulent state and found that the turbulent state cannot be described by the classic Goldreich-Sridhar phenomenology. We proposed a new phenomenological framework to describe this new kind of turbulent state.

(2) We have carried out a detailed analysis of the process of current sheet disruption due to the plasmoid instability, which triggers the transition from slow to fast reconnection.  We took two approaches, one being direct numerical simulations and the other being a phenomenological model. The corroboration between the two approaches puts out finding in a solid footing. We have identified the scalings of the disruption time, current sheet length, linear growth rate, and dominant wavenumber. The phenomenological model also gives a prediction for the critical Lundquist number for the current sheet disruption. 

(3) We found that the Si IV emission usually features a triangle-shaped line profile during the EUV burst events observed in IRIS. This type of triangle-shaped line profile can be explained by plasmoid-mediated turbulent reconnection, but not by the traditional Sweet-Parker or Petschek models of reconnection. Thus, the observation evidence supports the idea that these events are driven by plasmoid-mediated reconnection. We have performed numerical modeling for these events and compared synthetic line profile with observations.
